habitat: Grows on dead wood, alone or in pairs; found in Europe, North America, Canada, Mexico, Central America, and Asia; fruits in late summer/fall or winter/spring in warm areas.
shortDescription: A white fungus with long icicle-like spines, prized for culinary and medicinal uses.
benefitsOrToxicity: Supports brain and nerve health, cognitive function, immune system, digestive health, antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, anti-cancer properties; may lower blood sugar; may cause itchy skin or affect blood clotting.

identification.cap: Fruiting body 8–25 cm wide, unbranched clump of soft spines 1–4 cm long; white, may turn brownish or yellowish with age; attached to tough base on tree.
identification.flesh: White, soft, spongy; does not change color when sliced.
identification.microscopicFeatures: Spores 5–6 x 5.5–6 µm, globose to subglobose or subellipsoid, smooth or minutely roughened; hyaline; amyloid; gloeoplerous hyphae present, sometimes forming cystidia up to 50 x 6 µm.

medicinalProperties: Supports brain and nerve health, cognitive function, neuroprotection, immune system, digestive health, antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, anti-cancer, antioxidant activity.
note: Lion's Mane can be consumed as powder, extract, tea, coffee, tincture, gummies, or vitamins; caution advised for pregnancy, breastfeeding, blood clotting disorders, or surgery. Also safe for pets under guidance.
